articles.headline: I.R.S. to End Use of Facial Recognition for Identity Verification
articles.snippet: After a bipartisan backlash, the agency will transition away from using a service from ID.me.
articles.abstract: After a bipartisan backlash, the agency will transition away from using a service from ID.me.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service plans to stop using facial recognition software to identify taxpayers seeking access to their accounts on the agency’s website amid concerns over privacy and data security.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Kashmir Hill

articles.headline: Peter Thiel to Exit Meta’s Board to Support Trump-Aligned Candidates
articles.snippet: The tech billionaire, who has been on the board of the company formerly known as Facebook since 2005, is backing numerous politicians in the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: The tech billionaire, who has been on the board of the company formerly known as Facebook since 2005, is backing numerous politicians in the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peter Thiel, one of the longest-serving board members of Meta, the parent of Facebook, plans to step down, the company said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Supreme Court Restores Alabama Voting Map That a Court Said Hurt Black Voters
articles.snippet: A special three-judge court had ordered lawmakers to redraw the lines, saying Black voters “have less opportunity” than other Alabamians to elect their favored candidates.
articles.abstract: A special three-judge court had ordered lawmakers to redraw the lines, saying Black voters “have less opportunity” than other Alabamians to elect their favored candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday reinstated an Alabama congressional map that a lower court had said diluted the power of Black voters, suggesting that the court was poised to become more skeptical of challenges to voting maps based on claims of race discrimination.

articles.headline: As Protest Paralyzes Canada’s Capital, Far-Right Activists Abroad Embrace It
articles.snippet: It may be only a few hundred demonstrators occupying Ottawa’s streets to protest government overreach, but their message has aroused passions around the world.
articles.abstract: It may be only a few hundred demonstrators occupying Ottawa’s streets to protest government overreach, but their message has aroused passions around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Eleven days into an unruly occupation against coronavirus restrictions that has paralyzed Canada’s capital, the protests have become a rallying cry for powerful far-right and anti-vaccine groups around the world that have made the cause their own.
articles.byline: By Catherine Porter, Ian Austen and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Putin Warns the West and Ukraine, but Keeps His Intentions a Mystery
articles.snippet: President Vladimir Putin said diplomatic ideas raised in a meeting by French President Emmanuel Macron were worth pursuing, but did not rule out a Russian invasion of Ukraine.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir Putin said diplomatic ideas raised in a meeting by French President Emmanuel Macron were worth pursuing, but did not rule out a Russian invasion of Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin said he was prepared to keep negotiating over Russia’s security demands in Eastern Europe but offered a stark warning over the possibility of a full-scale war between Russia and the West — using a five-hour meeting with his French counterpart on Monday to keep the world guessing about his intentions.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Roger Cohen and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: As Officials Look Away, Hate Speech in India Nears Dangerous Levels
articles.snippet: Activists and analysts say calls for anti-Muslim violence — even genocide — are moving from the fringes to the mainstream, while political leaders keep silent.
articles.abstract: Activists and analysts say calls for anti-Muslim violence — even genocide — are moving from the fringes to the mainstream, while political leaders keep silent.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARIDWAR, India — The police officer arrived at the Hindu temple here with a warning to the monks: Don’t repeat your hate speech.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Suhasini Raj and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: Why This Could Be a Critical Year for Electric Cars
articles.snippet: Booming in a depressed market, battery-powered vehicles are a plus for the climate but pose a big threat to carmakers and parts suppliers that are slow to change.
articles.abstract: Booming in a depressed market, battery-powered vehicles are a plus for the climate but pose a big threat to carmakers and parts suppliers that are slow to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sales of cars powered solely by batteries surged in the United States, Europe and China last year, while deliveries of fossil fuel vehicles were stagnant. Demand for electric cars is so strong that manufacturers are requiring buyers to put down deposits months in advance. And some models are effectively sold out for the next two years.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Erik Prince Helped Raise Money for Conservative Spy Venture
articles.snippet: New details reveal the ambitions of an operation intended to infiltrate opponents of Donald Trump, including moderate Republicans as well as progressives and Democrats.
articles.abstract: New details reveal the ambitions of an operation intended to infiltrate opponents of Donald Trump, including moderate Republicans as well as progressives and Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During the summer of 2018, as Richard Seddon, a former British spy, was trying to launch a new venture to use undercover agents to infiltrate progressive groups, Democratic campaigns and other opponents of President Donald J. Trump, he turned for help to a longtime friend and former colleague: Erik Prince, the private military contractor.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: As Automakers Add Technology to Cars, Software Bugs Follow
articles.snippet: Faulty computer systems are prompting class-action lawsuits by disgruntled car owners, a symptom of automakers’ bumpy transition to the digital age.
articles.abstract: Faulty computer systems are prompting class-action lawsuits by disgruntled car owners, a symptom of automakers’ bumpy transition to the digital age.
articles.lead_paragraph: About six months after Gary Gilpin leased a Subaru Outback from a California dealer, the screen went blank and wouldn’t come back on. Mr. Gilpin took the car to the dealer for what he figured would be a quick reset.

articles.headline: Peloton’s future is uncertain after a swift fall from pandemic stardom.
articles.snippet: The chief executive stepped down as a glut of unsold machines, negative TV portrayals, activist investors and a recall plagued the fitness company.
articles.abstract: The chief executive stepped down as a glut of unsold machines, negative TV portrayals, activist investors and a recall plagued the fitness company.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Foley, the chief executive and a founder of Peloton, could barely contain his excitement.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: The U.S. trade deficit soared to a record last year.
articles.snippet: The widening deficit was driven by a $576.5 billion increase in imports last year, as Americans purchased more products made abroad.
articles.abstract: The widening deficit was driven by a $576.5 billion increase in imports last year, as Americans purchased more products made abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. trade deficit in goods soared to record levels in 2021, topping $1 trillion as Americans continued to spend heavily on computers, toys, bicycles, clothing, pharmaceuticals and other goods made in foreign factories during the pandemic.

articles.headline: Putin Is Operating on His Own Timetable, and It May Be a Long One
articles.snippet: The standoff between Russia and the West over Ukraine could turn into a drawn-out and dangerous diplomatic slog toward a difficult settlement.
articles.abstract: The standoff between Russia and the West over Ukraine could turn into a drawn-out and dangerous diplomatic slog toward a difficult settlement.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Ukraine crisis is here to stay.

articles.headline: J.&J. Pauses Production of Its Covid Vaccine Despite Persistent Need
articles.snippet: A crucial Johnson & Johnson plant has stopped making its Covid vaccine, though the company says it has millions of doses in inventory.
articles.abstract: A crucial Johnson & Johnson plant has stopped making its Covid vaccine, though the company says it has millions of doses in inventory.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson’s easy-to-deliver Covid-19 shot is the vaccine of choice for much of the developing world.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Robbins, Stephanie Nolen, Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
